speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The Federal Open Market Committee concluded its last meeting of the year earlier today.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As indicated in our policy statement, the FOMC “reaffirmed its view that the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate remains appropriate.” The Committee also updated its forward guidance for the federal funds rate, indicating that “the Committee judges that it can be patient in beginning to normalize the stance of monetary policy.” This new language does not represent a change in our policy intentions and is fully consistent with our previous guidance, which stated that it likely will be appropriate to maintain the current target range for the federal funds rate for a considerable time after the end of our asset purchase program.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But with that program having ended in October, and the economy continuing to make progress toward our objectives, the Committee judged that some modification to our guidance is appropriate at this time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I will have more to say about our policy decisions in a moment, but first let me review recent economic developments and the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: In the labor market, progress continues toward the FOMC’s objective of maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The pace of job growth has been strong recently, with job gains averaging nearly 280,000 per month over the past 3 months; over the past 12 months, job gains averaged nearly 230,000 per month.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The unemployment rate was 5.8 percent in November, three-tenths lower than the latest reading available at the time of the September FOMC meeting.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Broader measures of labor market utilization have shown similar improvement, and the labor force participation rate has leveled out.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As noted in the FOMC statement, “underutilization of labor resources continues to diminish.” Even so, there is room for further improvement, with too many people who want jobs being unable to find them, too many who are working part time but would prefer December 17, 2014 full-time work, and too many who have given up searching for a job but would likely do so if the Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL labor market were stronger.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The Committee continues to see sufficient underlying strength in the economy to support ongoing improvement in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Real GDP looks to have increased robustly in the third quarter, reflecting solid consumption and investment spending.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Smoothing through the quarterly ups and downs earlier this year, real GDP expanded around 2½ percent over the four quarters ending in the third quarter, and the available indicators suggest that economic growth is running at roughly that pace in the current quarter.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The Committee continues to expect a moderate pace of growth going forward.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Inflation has continued to run below the Committee’s 2 percent objective, and the recent sizable declines in oil prices will likely hold down overall inflation in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But as the effects of these oil price declines and other transitory factors dissipate and as resource utilization continues to rise, the Committee expects inflation to move gradually back toward its objective.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: In making this forecast, the Committee is mindful of the recent declines in market-based measures of inflation compensation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: At this point, the Committee views these movements as likely to prove transitory, and survey-based measures of longer-term inflation expectations have remained stable.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: That said, developments in this area obviously bear close watching.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: This outlook is reflected in the individual economic projections submitted in conjunction with this meeting by the FOMC participants.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As always, each participant’s projections are conditioned on his or her own view of appropriate monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The central tendency of the unemployment rate projections is slightly lower than in the September projections and now stands at 5.2 to 5.3 percent at the end of next year, in line with its estimated longer-run normal level.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Committee participants generally see the unemployment rate declining a little further over December 17, 2014 the course of 2016 and 2017.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The central tendency of the projections for real GDP growth is Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL 2.3 to 2.4 percent for 2014, up a bit from the September projections.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Over the next three years, the projections for real GDP growth run somewhat above the estimates of longer-run normal growth.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Finally, although FOMC participants project inflation in the near term to be lower on account of the decline in energy prices, they continue to see inflation moving gradually back toward 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The central tendency of the inflation projections is 1.0 to 1.6 percent next year, rising to 1.8 to 2.0 percent in 2017.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As I noted earlier, the Committee “reaffirmed its view that the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate remains appropriate.” Regarding forward guidance for the federal funds rate, our October statement indicated that it likely would be appropriate to maintain the current target range for the federal funds rate for a considerable time following the end of our asset purchase program, especially if projected inflation continues to run below the Committee’s 2 percent longer-run goal.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Today’s statement, which indicates that “the Committee judges that it can be patient in beginning to normalize the stance of monetary policy,” does not signify any change in the Committee’s policy intentions as set forth in its recent statements.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As before, this judgment is based on the Committee’s assessment of realized and expected progress toward its objectives of maximum employment and 2 percent inflation—an assessment that is based on a wide range of information, including measures of labor market conditions, indicators of inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and readings on financial developments.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Given that the Committee is not signaling a change in policy, why did we update our guidance?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The reason is that, with the asset purchase program having been wound down in October, it seemed less helpful to continue to communicate about the possible timing of our first rate increase with reference to an event that is receding into the past.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Instead, we have shifted to December 17, 2014 language that better reflects the Committee’s focus on the economic conditions that would make Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL liftoff appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Employment is rising at a healthy rate and the U.S. economy is strengthening, reflecting, in part, a highly accommodative stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Of course, inflation has been running somewhat below our goal of 2 percent, but we project that gap to close gradually over time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As progress in achieving maximum employment and 2 percent inflation continues, at some point it will become appropriate to begin reducing policy accommodation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But, based on its current outlook, the Committee judges that it can be patient in doing so.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: In particular, the Committee considers it unlikely to begin the normalization process for at least the next couple of meetings.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: This assessment, of course, is completely data dependent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: If incoming information indicates faster progress toward the Committee’s employment and inflation objectives than the Committee now expects, then increases in the target range for the federal funds rate are likely to occur sooner than currently anticipated.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Conversely, if progress proves slower than expected, then increases in the target range are likely to occur later than currently anticipated.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Once we begin to remove policy accommodation, it continues to be the Committee’s assessment that, “even after employment and inflation are near mandate-consistent levels, economic conditions may, for some time, warrant keeping the target federal funds rate below levels the Committee views as normal in the longer run.” This guidance is consistent with the paths for appropriate policy given by FOMC participants.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Assuming that the economy evolves broadly in line with participants’ expectations, almost all participants believe that it will be appropriate to begin raising the target range for the federal funds rate in 2015.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: There are a range of views on the appropriate timing of liftoff within the year, in part reflecting differences in participants’ expectations for how the economy will evolve.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: By the time December 17, 2014 of liftoff, participants expect to see some further decline in the unemployment rate and additional Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL improvement in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: They also expect core inflation to be running near current levels but foresee being reasonably confident in their expectation that inflation will move back toward our 2 percent longer-run inflation objective over time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Of course, as I previously emphasized, the timing of the initial rise in the federal funds rate target, as well as the path for the target thereafter, are contingent on economic conditions.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: By late 2016, the median projection for the federal funds rate, at 2.5 percent, remains more than 1 percentage point below the longer-run value of 3¾ percent or so projected by most participants, even though the central tendency of the unemployment rate by that time is slightly below its estimated longer-run value and the central tendency for inflation is close to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: FOMC participants provide a number of explanations for the federal funds rate running below its normal longer-run level at that time—in particular, the residual effects of the financial crisis, which are likely to continue to constrain household spending and constrain credit availability for some time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But as these factors dissipate further, most participants expect the federal funds rate to move close to its longer-run normal level by the end of 2017.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Finally, the Committee will continue its policy of reinvesting proceeds from maturing Treasury securities and principal payments from holdings of agency debt and MBS.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The Committee’s sizable holdings of longer-term securities should help maintain accommodative financial conditions and promote further progress toward our objectives of maximum employment and inflation of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Thank you, and I’ll be happy to take your questions.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: Jon Hilsenrath from the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: Chair Yellen, a number of Fed officials have projected in the lead-up to this meeting that the most likely timing December 17, 2014 for liftoff was around the middle of next year.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: I wonder if you could clarify that.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: You said in Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL your statement that “patient” means not for at least two meetings.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: Your forecast that—the FOMC’s forecasts seem to be consistent with something like a middle-of-the-year liftoff.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: Can you speak to that?

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: And can you also speak to the downdraft we’re seeing in inflation now and, in particular, the market-based inflation expectations and whether that gives the Committee any hesitance about proceeding towards liftoff in the months ahead?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I did say that the statement that the Committee can be patient should be interpreted as meaning that it is unlikely to begin the normalization process for at least the next couple of meetings.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Now, that doesn’t point to any preset or predetermined time at which normalization is—will begin.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: There are a range of views on the Committee, and it will be dependent on how incoming data bear on the progress the economy is making.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: First of all, I want to emphasize that no meeting is completely off the table, in the sense that if we do see faster progress toward our objectives than we currently expect, then it is possible that the process of normalization would occur sooner than we now anticipate.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, of course, the converse is also true.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, at this point, we think it unlikely that it will be appropriate—that we will see conditions for at least the next couple of meetings that will make it appropriate—for us to decide to begin normalization.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: A number of Committee participants have indicated that, in their view, conditions could be appropriate by the middle of next year, but there is no preset time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And there are a range of views as to when the appropriate conditions will likely fall in place.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So that’s something we will be watching closely as the year unfolds.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: You asked also, I think, about inflation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, as I mentioned in my press statement, especially with the downward pressures on inflation that we expect to see for a little while because of declining oil prices and falling import prices, we certainly expect headline inflation to December 17, 2014 be under downward pressure for a while.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, as I mentioned, most participants do envision that Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL conditions will be appropriate sometime during this coming year to begin normalizing policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And they do largely expect that inflation will be—core inflation will probably be running close to its current level.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And headline inflation could even be lower.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But what they will want to have is a feeling of reasonable confidence that when we start the process of normalizing policy, that it will be moving up over time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, of course, as labor market conditions continue to improve, history suggests that as long as inflation expectations remain well anchored, that that’s likely to occur.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Marty Crutsinger with the Associated Press.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Given the—what’s happening now with the transition with the Fed, there seems to be a pattern developing that the market expects big news to come when you have a press conference and no news to come when you don’t have one.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: But is that a good expectation?

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: And is there any thought to starting to have a press conference at every meeting?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I would really like to discourage that expectation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Every meeting that we have is a live meeting at which the Committee could make a policy decision.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And we will feel free to do so.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I would really like to strongly discourage the expectation that policy moves can only occur when there’s a scheduled press conference.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And we have long had in place the ability to hold a press conference call, rather than an in-person press conference.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And we did do so on a number of occasions in earlier years.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So the Committee, clearly, would want to be able to explain its reasoning.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As we begin the process of normalizing policy, every meeting is live.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And if we were to decide at a meeting to begin to normalize policy, I expect we would hold a press conference call.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Was there concern—Steve Liesman, CNBC—was there concern expressed at the meeting that the signal coming from markets—and a variety of markets—lower oil prices, lower yields around the world, was one of deflation, and that that risk was one that should, perhaps, overshadow the concern about inflation on the other side?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Well, thanks Steve.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We’re very attentive to global developments and certainly discuss them in the meeting.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The very substantial decline we have seen in oil prices is one of the most important developments shaping the global outlook.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It will have different effects in different regions and could well have effects on financial markets, as we are seeing.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I think the judgment of the Committee is that, from the standpoint of the United States and the U.S. outlook, that the decline we have seen in oil prices is likely to be, on net, a positive.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It’s something that’s certainly good for families, for households.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It’s putting more money in their pockets.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Having to spend less on gas and energy, and so, in that sense, it’s like a tax cut that boosts their spending power.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The United States remains—although our production of oil has increased dramatically, we still remain a net importer of oil.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Of course there may be some offset in the form of reduced drilling activity, and possibly some change, some reduction in cap-ex plans in the drilling area.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But, on balance, I would see these developments as a positive for the standpoint of the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: With respect to deflation, we see downward pressure on headline inflation from declining energy prices.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We certainly recognize that that is going to be pushing down headline inflation and may even spill over, to some extent, to core inflation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But, at this point, although we indicated we’re monitoring inflation developments carefully, we see these developments as transitory.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And the Committee continues to believe—especially with the improvement we’re seeing in the labor market, which we expect to continue—that inflation will move back up to our December 17, 2014 2 percent objective over time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As I indicated, we will want to feel, I believe, that people will Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL expect to feel reasonably confident about that when they—when the process of normalization begins.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But we do expect them to be transitory.

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: Robin Harding from the Financial Times.

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: Madame Chair, there’s a big gap between the pace markets expect you to raise interest rates and the rate you’ve indicated in your “dot plot.” Are markets misunderstanding your intentions?

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So that’s difficult for me to say.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: What I want to say is that our objective is to communicate as clearly as we possibly can about our plans and how we see the economic environment unfolding.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: When the participants in the Committee fill out their projections, they’re asked to give the path of the federal funds rate and of the various economic variables that they consider most likely.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: They’re not asked to talk about all the different things that could happen, recognizing there is uncertainty, and the paths of the funds rate that they would consider appropriate if those other alternatives were to happen.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But other alternatives, I think, are priced into the market.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And one reason that the market prices may be different than the Committee’s is because they place probability on other outcomes that look different than what they regard as the modal forecast.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: They may also have a different set of expectations about how the—about the economic outlook and how it’s likely to unfold.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I recognize that there are significant differences.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I can’t tell you exactly what they’re due to.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But what I do want to do is communicate as clearly as I can, on behalf of the Committee, how we think the economy’s likely to progress and how we would likely set the federal funds rate over time if that forecast bears out.

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: It doesn’t make you uncomfortable, where markets are now?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: There are a number of different factors that are bearing on the path of market interest rates, I think, including global economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It is often the case that when oil prices move down and the dollar appreciates, that that tends to put downward pressure on inflation compensation and on longer-term rates.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We also have safe-haven flows that may be affecting longer-term Treasury yields.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I can’t tell you exactly what is driving market developments.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But what I can say is that we are trying to communicate our thoughts as clearly as we can.

speaker: STEVEN MUFSON
sentence: Hi.

speaker: STEVEN MUFSON
sentence: Steve Mufson from the Washington Post.

speaker: STEVEN MUFSON
sentence: I was just hoping you could go into a little more detail about the oil effect.

speaker: STEVEN MUFSON
sentence: Even though you see it as transitory, does that give you a little more room to keep rates low in the next few months?

speaker: STEVEN MUFSON
sentence: And if—alternately, if prices bounce back, what’s that going to do to your ability to change rates, and how might you react to that?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Well I—I’d say, you know, that I think what we have seen since the mid-’80s is that, in an environment where inflation expectations are well anchored, that movements in oil and commodity prices and import prices tend to have transitory effects on the inflation outlook.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: There were many years in which we had unanticipated increases in oil prices, really beginning in 2004 and 2005, that put upward pressure on headline inflation and sometimes even spilled through into core, and, typically, the Committee looked through those impacts on inflation with the view that they would be transitory.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I think experience bears out that they were transitory.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I think that’s the Committee’s expectation here.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Inflation, even core inflation, has been running below our inflation objective.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Movements in oil, you know, now down and perhaps later up, will move inflation around, certainly headline inflation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But the Committee, at this point, anticipates those impacts to be transitory.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So as long as participants December 17, 2014 feel reasonably confident that the inflation projection is one where we expect to meet our Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL 2 percent objective over time, that’s what I think how they’ll be looking at things as we decide on the path for the funds rate.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: Binya Appelbaum, New York Times.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: Does “a couple” mean two?

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: And when you talk about reasonable confidence in inflation expectations, can you elaborate a little bit about what it would take to give you reasonable confidence that inflation is headed back to 2 percent?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So “a couple”—I believe the dictionary probably says, “a couple” means two.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, “a couple” means two.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And with respect to inflation—our forecast for inflation and inflation expectations, let me start by saying I think it’s important that monetary policy be forward looking.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The lags in monetary policy are long, and, therefore, the Committee has to base its decisions on how to set the federal funds rate looking into the future.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Theory is important, and theories that are consistent with historical evidence will be something that governs the thinking of many people around the table.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Typically, we have seen that as long as inflation expectations are well anchored, that as the labor market recovers, we’ll gradually see upward pressure on both wages and prices, and that inflation will tend to move back toward 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I think historically we have seen, as the economy strengthens and slack diminishes, that inflation does tend to gradually rise over time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And as long—you know, I—just speaking for myself, I will be looking for evidence that I think strengthens my confidence in that view and, you know, looking at the full range of data that bear on whether or not that’s a reasonable view of how events will unfold.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But it’s likely to be a decision that’s based on forecasts and confidence in the forecast.

speaker: MICHAEL FLAHERTY
sentence: Michael Flaherty, Reuters News.

speaker: MICHAEL FLAHERTY
sentence: Chair Yellen, a lot of attention has been focused on liftoff.

speaker: MICHAEL FLAHERTY
sentence: But, I wonder, has the Committee discussed what happens after that liftoff and what, you know, the rate path would be after you make the first move?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, I think you raise a very important point because, although there is a great deal of market focus on the timing of liftoff, what to matter in thinking about the stance of policy is what the entire path of interest rates will look like.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I really don’t have much for you other than to say that they will be data dependent—that, over time, the stance of policy will be adjusted to try to keep the economy on a track where we see continuing progress toward achieving our goals of maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: There’s—you know, the federal funds rate has been sitting in the 0 to ¼ percent range now for six years.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: This is—and we have a very large balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We are providing a very highly accommodative monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And even as we begin to normalize the stance of monetary policy, when that becomes appropriate, it’s important to remember that monetary policy will still be very accommodative for a long time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And as we begin to normalize policy, we will be looking at unfolding economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And as the economy strengthens, and we come closer to achieving our objectives, I think it’s very likely that we will, you know, progress on the path of normalizing policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But I can’t tell you, specifically, other than saying it will depend on progress, and moves will be data dependent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I can’t say much more than that.

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: Chair Yellen, the Committee’s projections show unemployment running below your own views on where full employment should be for the next several years.

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: Does that reflect a desire on the part of the Committee that the economy run somewhat above potential for a while?

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: And, if so, can you elaborate on why it wants that and what purpose it achieves?

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: And, related to the question that Jon Hilsenrath asked earlier, you’ve called the decline in inflation— December 17, 2014 and market-based measures of inflation expectations—transitory.

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: But this decline has been very Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL pronounced in the five-year-forward range.

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: So we’re talking about expectations that inflation many years from now will be below target.

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: And some market participants see that as evidence of declining credibility in the Committee’s long-term objective.

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: Why do you still view that as transitory?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So you—your first question is: Why is it that the Committee sees unemployment as declining slightly below its estimate of the longer-run natural rate?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, I think, in part, the reason for that is that inflation is running below our objective, and the Committee wants to see inflation move back toward our objective over time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And a short period of a very slight undershoot of unemployment below the natural rate will facilitate a slightly faster return of inflation to our objective.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It is, I should say, a very small undershoot in a situation where there is great uncertainty about exactly what constitutes maximum employment or a longer-run normal rate of unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We also do see the different measures of slack in the labor market point to different assessments of just what maximum employment is.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The standard unemployment rate, for quite some time now, has been signaling a little bit less slack in the labor market than measures that are somewhat broader that, for example, include the unusually large number of people who were part-time employed but would prefer full-time jobs.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And the portion of the decline we’ve seen in labor force participation, that looks like it would disappear in a—or be eroded in a stronger economy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And so it may be that with a very small undershoot of this longer-run normal level of the unemployment rate, as measured by the standard unemployment rate, we’ll be seeing some further progress on those other margins of slack.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But it’s important to point out that the Committee is not anticipating an overshoot of its 2 percent inflation objective.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Oh, and longer-dated expectations.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Well, what I would say, we refer to this in the statement as “inflation compensation” rather than “inflation expectations.” The gap between the nominal yields on 10-year Treasuries, for example, and TIPS have declined—that’s inflation compensation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And five-year, five-year-forwards, as you’ve said, have also declined.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: That could reflect a change in inflation expectations, but it could also reflect changes in assessment of inflation risks.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The risk premium that’s necessary to compensate for inflation, that might especially have fallen if the probabilities attached to very high inflation have come down.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And it can also reflect liquidity effects in markets.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, for example, it’s sometimes the case that—when there is a flight to safety, that flight tends to be concentrated in nominal Treasuries and could also serve to compress that spread.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I think the jury is out about exactly how to interpret that downward move in inflation compensation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And we indicated that we are monitoring inflation developments carefully.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: Madame Chair, Peter Cook of Bloomberg Television.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: I want to follow up, if I could, on firming going forward, on the normalization once liftoff takes place.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: I know you said this is going to be data dependent.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: Does that suggest to markets, to those watching, that the measured pace we’ve seen in a previous tightening cycle, those quarter-point increments, that that’s not something markets should expect?

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: And what’s your own takeaway from how effective that measured pace was back in that previous tightening cycle?

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: And if I could follow up just separately on the dissents at this meeting.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: There were three dissents, a notable number, certainly.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: What does that suggest about the debate around the table and your ability to forge consensus going forward?

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: Are you disappointed with the number of dissents?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So let me start with the number of dissents.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: There is a wide range of opinion in the Committee.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I think it’s appropriate for people to be able to express their views.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, in a sense, you see dissents on both sides.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I think the statement does a good job of reflecting what the majority of the Committee thinks is appropriate policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So at—you know, at a time like this, where we are making consequential decisions, I think it’s very reasonable to see divergences of opinion.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And just remind me, what was the other—about the— PETER COOK.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Measured pace.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: —measured pace.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: There certainly has been no, you know, decision on the part of the Committee to move at a measured pace or to use language like that.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I think quite a few people, looking back on the use of that language in the—I can’t remember if it was 12 or 16 meetings, where there were 25 basis point moves.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We’d probably not like to repeat a sequence in which there was a measured pace and 25 basis point moves at every meeting.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I certainly don’t want to encourage you to think that there will be a repeat of that.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Many members of the Committee, participants, have said that they think policy should be based on the actual evolution of economic activity and inflation, which tends to be variable over time, and that’s why I say I anticipate it will be data dependent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We have continued to provide guidance, the same guidance that we have for some time, that says the Committee “anticipates that, even after employment and inflation are near mandate-consistent levels, economic conditions may, for some time, warrant keeping the target federal funds rate below levels the Committee views as normal in the longer run.” I know that’s a mouthful, but it says, in effect, that the Committee believes that the economic conditions that have made recovery difficult, we’re getting beyond them.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: They are optimistic that those conditions will lift.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: They see the longer-run normal level of interest rates as December 17, 2014 around 3¾ percent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So there’s no view in the Committee that there is secular stagnation in the Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL sense that we won’t eventually get back to pretty historically normal levels of interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But they have said, it’ll, you know, the economy has required to get where it is a good deal of monetary policy accommodation; we expect to be able to normalize policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But, until those conditions have lifted that have held back economic activity, monetary policy will need to stay accommodative.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, in that sense, perhaps that’s equivalent to saying that the path of normalization is anticipated to be relatively gradual.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But, again, the path of rates will depend on how economic conditions actually evolve, and that’s nothing more than an expectation on the part of the Committee.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: Pedro da Costa with Dow Jones Newswires.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: Enough about rates.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: I want to ask you about the New York Fed.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: The New York Fed’s been in the news a lot lately.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: President Dudley was invited to Congress to testify about conflicts of interest there.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: You had things like the Segarra tapes, the Beim report, and, most recently, the revelation that a former New York Fed official was exchanging information with someone at Goldman Sachs who was also—had New York Fed connections.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: I just wonder—and also there were scandals during the crisis related to Stephen Friedman regarding the New York Fed, and his purchase of Goldman Sachs stock.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: Do you see the New York Fed as a black mark on the Fed system because of these recurring scandals?

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: Have you talked to Bill Dudley about reforming the image of that particular regional Fed?

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: And do you think a person that has—that spent 21 years of his career at Goldman Sachs is in a position to regain public credibility about conflicts of interest?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Well, let me say that I think it’s very important for the Federal Reserve System to have confidence in the quality of its supervision.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I do have a good deal of confidence in the quality of our supervision program, for the banking organizations we December 17, 2014 supervise in general, and that also applies to the largest banking organizations.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We rely on Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL examiners who are in the field and at the Reserve Banks to be providing information about what’s happening in those organizations.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But that information feeds into a process in which it is not individuals at any single Reserve Bank.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But, at the Board, it’s a Board-led process, and it involves senior officials at a number of different Reserve Banks.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It’s also a multidisciplinary process that involves not only people from supervision, but those from markets, from economic research.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Experts who focus on financial stability all come together to evaluate the information that they have and to assign supervisory ratings and decide on the appropriate program for all of those large institutions.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We’ve strengthened the process of supervision enormously since the crisis, and I feel a very good sense of confidence in how we’re carrying that out.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Now, it is important to make sure that we have fed into this process all the information that’s relevant to making the right decisions.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And when there are individuals who are examiners, who may disagree with others in their team about how to interpret what’s going on at a particular institution, it’s important that there be channels by which they can make sure that disagreements are fed up to the highest levels.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: This is true throughout the work we do.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We do economic forecasting, and our—the FOMC receives information to help us make decisions, but obviously there are disagreements about—among economists about how to interpret developments.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It’s also important for us there to make sure we understand alternative views.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So this is important in supervision.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We’ve announced that the Board has undertaken a review of whether or not there are appropriate mechanisms in place in all of the Reserve Banks that individuals who disagree with decisions can make their own views known and feed into the process, and we’ve also asked our inspector general to look into that.

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: Jeff Kearns from Bloomberg News.

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: I’d also like to get off monetary policy and ask you about the Federal Reserve’s relationship with Congress.

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: Specifically, how worried are you about legislation that has been proposed, and may be proposed again in the next Congress, that would reduce Fed independence?

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: Would you see yourself trying to fight back?

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: Or would you see yourself trying to go to Congress to work with them to do more with transparency or something else to reduce their concerns without making them law?

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: And, if there were bills sent to the White House, would you talk to the President about vetoing them?

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: Or do you have any confidence that he would veto bills that would reduce the Fed’s independence?

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So let me simply say that Congress has assigned us important tasks in monetary policy and in other roles that we perform, and the Federal Reserve is highly focused on attempting to carry out the mandates that Congress has given us in the area of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It’s our dual mandate to promote maximum employment and price stability, and that’s what we’re working on.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: You know, I would say that the ability of a central bank to make the decisions about monetary policy that it regards as in the best longer-run interests of the economy, free of short-run political interference, is very important to the effective conduct of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I think that history shows, not only in the United States but around the world, that central bank independence promotes better economic performance.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I do think central bank independence is very important, and that it’s important to make sure that we can make the decisions we think are best, free of short-run political interference with respect to monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We should be accountable, and we are accountable to Congress in explaining what we do.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I believe strongly in transparency, and I believe strongly that we should communicate as clearly December 17, 2014 what we are doing and the rationale for doing it, and I am very open to looking for ways Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL ourselves to improve our communications and transparency, and working with Congress to do that.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But I would be very concerned about actions.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Back in 1978, Congress explicitly passed legislation to ensure that there would be no GAO audits of monetary policy decisionmaking— namely, policy audits.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I certainly hope that will continue, and I will try to forcefully make the case for why that’s important.

speaker: JEFF KEARNS
sentence: Would it veto?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I cannot speak for the White House.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I wouldn’t attempt to do that.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Peter Barnes of Fox Business, ma’am.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: And also, I’ll stay off of interest rates.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: And first, I want to wish you happy holidays.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: And, second, I want to ask you about the Russian economy.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Did that come up in the meeting in your discussion about the global economic developments?

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: As you know, there’s a lot of concern that with the drop in oil prices, the Russian economy could be in some trouble.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Russia owes a lot of money to U.S. and foreign banks and Russian companies.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Is there any concern about default?

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Any concern about possible contagion?

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: And, if so, has the Fed taken any steps to prepare for that?

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Well, we certainly did review global economic developments, including developments in the Russian economy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Clearly, Russia has been hit very hard by the decline in oil prices, and the ruble has depreciated enormously in value, and this is posing a series of very difficult economic conditions in the Russian economy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Of course we discussed what the potential spillovers are to the United States, which could occur both through trade and financial linkages.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But these linkages are actually relatively small.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: December 17, 2014 Russia accounts for less than 1 percent of U.S. trade volume, and U.S. banks’ exposure to Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL Russian residents is really quite small in terms of—relative to their capital.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: In terms of the portfolios of U.S. residents, there are Russian securities, but they are—they account for a very small share.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I expect that the linkages back to the spillovers to the United States, both through trade and financial channels, would be small.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Europe, of course, is somewhat more exposed to Russia, both because Russia is an important supplier of oil and natural gas to Europe and the financial linkages are somewhat greater.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But, in the case of the United States, I see the spillovers relative—it is pretty small.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But we’re obviously watching that closely.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Greg Robb from MarketWatch.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Also, happy holidays.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Same to you.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: There’s a contagion risk to the—from low oil prices that people are talking about in the markets.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: What does it mean to the banks that have lent, you know, into the oil patch with the low oil prices?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And I guess, you know, your warnings about leveraged loans—you have made warnings over the past year about leveraged lending.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Are you worried that they haven’t been heeded?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, I mean, there is some—you’re talking about in the United States exposure?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I mean, we have seen some impacts of lower oil prices on the spreads for high-yield bonds, where there’s exposure to oil companies that may see distress or a decline in their earnings, and we have seen some increase in spreads on high-yield bonds more generally.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I think for the banking system, as a whole, the exposure to oil—I’m not aware of significant issues there.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: This is the kind of thing that is part of risk management for banking organizations and the kind of thing they look at in stress tests.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But the movements in oil prices have been very large and undoubtedly unexpected.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We—in terms of leverage, and whether or not levered entities could be badly affected by movements in oil prices, leverage in the financial system, in general, is way down from the levels before the crisis.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So it’s not a major concern that there are levered entities that would be badly affected by this, but we’ll have to watch carefully.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: There have been large and unexpected movements in oil prices.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: Good afternoon, Chair Yellen.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: Steve Beckner of MNI.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: I will go back to interest rates, if you don’t mind.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: Actually, it’s a question about balance sheet effects on the overall appropriate level of monetary policy.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: In reaffirming the reinvestment policy, the FOMC says, once again, that this will help maintain accommodative financial conditions.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: In the past, it’s said that the large portfolio of securities will exert a downward effect on long-term interest rates.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: As you look forward to raising short-term rates, to what extent does the FOMC need to take into account this sort of residual, accommodative effect of maintaining a large balance sheet?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I agree, and that’s why we stated that we typically think of the monetary policy impact of our asset purchases as depending on the stock of assets that we hold on our balance sheet rather than the flow of purchases, and so we’re reminding the public that we continue to hold a large stock of assets, and that is tending to push down term premiums in longer-term yields.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We made clear when we—or tried to make clear—when we issued our normalization principles in September that we intend to use changes in our target for the federal funds rate as the main tool that we will actively use to adjust financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Rather than actively planning to sell the assets that we’ve put onto our balance sheet, sometime after we begin raising our targets for short-term interest rates, depending on economic and financial conditions, we’re likely to reduce or cease reinvestment and gradually run down the stock of our December 17, 2014 assets.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But our active tool for adjusting monetary—the stance of monetary policy so that it is Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL appropriate for the economic needs for the country, that will be done through adjusting our short-term target range for the federal funds rate.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: Kevin Hall with McClatchy Newspapers.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: I can’t believe nobody’s asked you the most important question, about what’s going on with your San Francisco 49ers, since everybody’s already wished you a happy holiday.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: Can you talk a little bit about housing?

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: Few things are more important to Americans in their wealth creation than housing.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: You’ve, in your statement, noted that it continues to be a drag.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: Mr. Dudley has—was actually relatively upbeat in his forecast.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: I don’t know if that’s a view shared on the Committee.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: What do you think is holding housing back?

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: What can Congress do?

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: What will you tell Congress in the coming year?

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: And more—and a clarification on the Dudley question from earlier.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: You didn’t mention him by name in your being pleased by quality of supervision.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: Are you pleased with Mr. Dudley’s handling of the events?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So let me start with that.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I have great confidence in President Dudley.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: He’s done a fine job in running the New York Fed, and I want to be very clear that I have great confidence in him.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: He’s a distinguished public servant, and he has worked very hard in the aftermath of the crisis to make sure that the New York Fed is doing all that it needs to do to contribute to the work that we do both in financial stability and in supervision.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And let’s see, the other question that you asked was about— KEVIN HALL.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Housing.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: —about housing.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, you know, I’ve been surprised that housing hasn’t recovered more robustly than it has.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: In part, I think it reflects very tight credit—continuing tight credit conditions for any borrower that doesn’t have really pristine credit, you December 17, 2014 know, credit ratings, and my hope is that that situation will ease over time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: In addition, Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL household formation has been very depressed, and my expectation is that, as the labor market continues to improve and households feel better about their financial condition, that we will see household formation pick up and a somewhat stronger recovery than we’ve seen thus far in housing.
